title: IT Support Technician Interview

Interview Descriptions: Asked typical questions about past employment experience and other information. Couple of technical questions and questions about past projects and scenarios. Overall not too bad of an interview process. There was quite a wait between the initial response though and the followup

title: Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by the hiring manager to schedule an interview, and then completely ghosted before the interview despite responding to their request on the same day. Extremely unprofessional. I'll edit this review if they contact me later with a legitimate reason for ghosting, but as of right I haven't heard anything.
Interview Questions: They asked me to call them back, and then they ghosted me.

title: Visiting Researcher Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Short process directly with the PI of the lab. Asked for two recommendation letters form previous lab experiences as well as a call with him and some of his PhD students.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have with research ? What experience do you have with [topic of the lab]? How independent are you ?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: I did 3 interviews. Two with the lab, and one with HR. Really depends on the lab, but my interviews were really friendly! The HR one was more situational (typical HR interview)
Interview Questions: How do you fit within this role

title: Communications and Programs Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard University in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: I briefly talked to the recruiter via email, who told me I would progress forward in the interviewing process. I then met with the two hiring managers for the role via Zoom. This process has been, by far, the most drawn-out, agitating, and frustrating experience I have had as a candidate in a while. After my first Zoom interview with the hiring managers for the role, I was told they would get back to me within two weeks. OK- I can handle that. Two weeks later, I got an email from the hiring manager telling me that the first round of interviews were still being scheduled and that they were delayed. But they would reach back out to me as soon as possible with the next steps in the process. Well, that time has come and gone, and I haven't been updated. My frustration with Harvard's process is two-fold: Recruiters are supposed to ensure that candidates are kept warm in the pipeline so they don't lose talent. Recruiters are also supposed to act as a middle person between a candidate and a hiring manager to ensure that the process is moving smoothly and without delays. I only got to interact with my recruiter ONCE. And then it was like they dropped off the face of the planet. I've had this phenomenon happen numerous times at this institution. It makes me wonder what the recruiters do at Harvard because it isn't recruiting. My second frustration is with higher education's recruiting process as a whole. I don't know if Harvard is entirely relying on their namesake, which is why they have no real sense of urgency in their hiring process, or if the bureaucracy within this school is just THAT ridiculous, but don't be in a hurry to find a job. Because Harvard certainly isn't in a hurry to hire you. All in all, this entire process has been deflating.
Interview Questions: How do you handle working under pressure?

title: Customer Service Representative Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Harvard University (New York, NY) in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: 2. Responding to customer inquiries: This is the primary responsibility of a chat support specialist. You will be expected to respond to customer inquiries promptly and efficiently. 3. Resolving customer issues: You will need to identify and troubleshoot customer issues and provide solutions to ensure customer satisfaction. 4. Providing product information: You will be required to have a thorough understanding of the product or service you are supporting and be able to provide accurate information to customers. 5. Escalating issues: You will need to escalate complex or unresolved issues to the appropriate department or team member for further assistance.
Interview Questions: What’s your name sir please

title: Data Privacy and Information Security Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and spoke with the recruiter month after. She shared that the hiring manager is new an joined from Stanford University. She shared that the comp is around 190k and the hiring manager has already reviewed my application.Next step was to setup a call with the new hiring manager. After that the recruiter ghosted me. I saw a linked post where somebody asked the recruiter about ghosting. I bet they will hire somebody cheap. But shame in the hiring manager for disrespect(dont care about recruiters as they dont have any skills)
Interview Questions: General about my background and compensation

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Non-existent. Applied for a role, felt I was qualified, they didn't contact me. Months later I received notification that they chose a different candidate. Very disappointed. The page is making me share >30 words, and I'm detailing an interview that never happened.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Nov 2022
Interview Descriptions: I received an email about the positioning opening, and reached out through a provided email address with my resume. I was asked to interview, which took place over Zoom. The interview was quick, only lasting about 20 minutes.

title: Business Analyst Interview

title: Software Developer Interview

Interview Descriptions: Harvard employs a 1-on-1 only interview process. There were about 7 in total, a light coding assessment but largely a high-level process to assess knowledge and willingness to learn rather than expertise.

title: Admissions Coordinator Interview

title: Marketing Manager Interview

title: Admin Interview

title: Program Assistant Interview

Interview Descriptions: Director was honest about the position and asked meaningful questions related to the job, its perks, benefits, and daily duty.  Nice and friendly, no pressure ever felt. It was a smooth experience for me.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Very good. They were timely and to the point. I felt comfortable  asking about the what the role looked like off of paper and felt like I received honest information from them.

title: Staff Assistant Interview

- Group interview with hiring managers. they asked about project management skills ,what did you do when a project went array/how did you handle it,
- Beware that it's avery long process, not difficult but very time consuming

title: Graduate Student Interview

title: Student Leader Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: There was a cover letter application and resume submission, and then there was no interview process. You were selected to receive the job or not based on your resume and cover letter.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed with the researcher of the project  for the position at The Pedagogy of Play project, Project Zero, Harvard Graduate School of Education. Their handling of applications and interviews in my case are quite unprofessional. After sending the first email with all the application materials, I waited for several weeks and followed up one more time before the recruiter finally received my materials. She then administered an interview invitation but attempted to change the interview time last minute to that very evening right before the original scheduled interview date. After the interview, she just ghosted the follow-up emails asking about the status (one sent after a week and another after several). Up to date (several months later), I still have no idea what was going on with my application. This whole interview definitely felt like a waste of my time and energy.
Interview Questions:
What kind of research have you done?
Any question about the project?

title: Technical Support Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions:
This was through a third-party recruiter who set up for me to have a video interview for the second round.  The interviewer was 3 minutes late to the meeting and made no apologies for this. After a brief greeting, he started avoiding all attempts at eye contact and even did their best to hide their whole body from the camera so no more than the background full of books were present while he asked me to provide an overview of my resume. I trailed off as I realized this . he then went to reiterate the job responsibilities and how its just one person who needs technical support for 10 minutes until I interjected and said, " I understand" and started asking him questions about the company and in depth pain points needed to be addressed in the role.  The interview was supposed to 30 minutes but only last 22 minutes. I felt so disrespected during the whole interview which is why I was shocked that they wanted to perform another one. This  time it was with the head of the company who performed the same behavior as the last but went farther with this disrespectful and unprofessional display of behavior by placing their head down on the desk as I was talking. I was not making unprofessional gestures mind you. Nor did I ramble. kept my replies under 2 minutes and it wasn't until I laughed that the interviewer lifted her head up. They chewed up the rest of the meeting by rambling until the end of the interview. 

Never have I ever felt so degraded, belittled, and mortified in my life. They completely disrespected my time. Were unprofessional. if you did not want the candidate then you simply should have said, " we would like to move in another direction."
Interview Questions: What are your qualifications for this role?

title: Janitor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: Asked me to sweep some floors and about my previous experience, great manager and environment to work for - everyone seems very nice. Seems like lots of opportunities to move up
Interview Questions: What's your experience with janitorial services

Then why bother asking me to do an in-person interview? Worst interviewing experience ever.

title: Coordinator Interview

title: Coordinator Interview

Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Met with two Human Resources representatives, with the direct supervisor, and the Associate Dean, separately, over a two month period. The meetings with the first human resources representative, direct supervisor, and associate dean were very friendly and pleasant. The final meeting with the hiring human resources representative--the salary negotiation--was very unpleasant; there was zero negotiation, all my asks were immediately shot down; her response was basically: either take it as it is or, we have plenty more people we can hire  for less than you.
Interview Questions: The main ask on the HR rep. part was for me to take the position as exempt, even though, technically, it should have been a non-exempt (union) position.

title: Lab Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Dallas, TX) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process required 4 different interviews. The first was a phone interview with a recruiter. The second was a team interview. The third interview was with the Assistant Dean. The final interview was with another team.
Interview Questions:
Why do you believe you are a good fit for this position? Have you ever worked with students before?
What technical skills do you possess?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Two interviews over Zoom; one with immediate supervisors and one with a larger group. Generally they would interview in person. The process took a few months from application to final offer.
Interview Questions: How do you handle working in collaborative environments

title: for HUIT Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: first round is a Phone interview and second round is in person interview. Phone interview is to get to know your background and see how your previous experience matches with the open positions. Second round, you meet up with a manager and a HR person .
Interview Questions:
asking behavioral questions
Tell me time you had a conflict with the team?
What's your weakness and strength?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Initial phone screen with HR, then 45 min interview. HR rep was very friendly, asked general questions about fit for position, relevant skills etc. Actual interview with supervisor was very casual, mostly a conversation rather than Q&A.
Interview Questions: What are the top skills you think this position needs?

title: Staff Attorney Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Overview:  Comprehensive, well-organized and fair. The first interview: One recruiter posed questions of me.  The second interview: Several managers participated in the interview. The third  segment: A written exercise. There was a mandatory written exercise. The rules required the job candidate to review and to analyze two legal briefs and then to write a memorandum, on a time limited basis.
Interview Questions: At the end of the interview, I was asked to share something about my personal interests/extra-curricular activities.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: The Human Resources team is very direct and communicative. However, if they don't want you for a role, they will just stop responding even after several rounds of interviews. If they do want you, they will be very communicative.
Interview Questions: How does your prior experience apply to this role?

title: Special Assistant to the Executive Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: You apply to the job posting and hear back from them about a month later. If you move on, it starts with a phone screening with someone from HR. About. 10 min phone call. Then there are 3 interviews with different people which can take about 2-4 weeks to hear back after each round. I applied end of February and didnt conclude the 4th interview until late June
Interview Questions: What are you hoping to get from this position. What is your end goal?

title: Director of Business Development Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I received an email from Human Resources. The call was over zoom video. It lasted about 45 minutes it was very cordial. However, it's been over a month and I haven'r heard back. I was told they will be in touch soon.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this job

title: Senior Events Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions:
Phone screening
In person interview with hiring manager
Second in person interview to meet the team 
Offer
But very slow process and you shouldn’t expect it to take less than a month at the fastest
Interview Questions: What did you do at your last position. That would make you a good fit for this position

title: Managing Director Alumni Affairs Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions:
1) phone screen
2) 4 Zoom meetings; 1/2 hour each; with hiring director, peers, and direct reports
3) would have been more zoom meetings with members of senior management, but I did not make that level
Interview Questions: Why did I choose to apply for this job at Harvard?

title: Lecturer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Asked about research and teaching, the usual questions that one would expect in an academic interview. I wouldn't say that I was surprised by much that I encountered in this very typical interview.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your research.

title: Preceptor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Ghosted for more than 4 months before basically no interview, hired on the spot. Was kinda anticlimatic, clearly someone had backed out. Wasn't asked anything about my preparation, just asked about management experience.
Interview Questions: How would you deal with a student who wants a grade change?

title: Executive Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: I had an initial call with the HR consultant, and the call went well and was told I would hear back in a week. I followed up with a thank you note, the next day. One week went day, then two weeks. I sent another note to request an update. Now the issues that is frustrating to me is that the individual, Benjamin Norton didn’t even bother to 1. Follow up 2. Respond to my second email requesting an update, instead he sent a generic rejection email. The lack of communication is unprofessional and extremely rude.
Interview Questions: Behavioral questions regarding management experience.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: very easy, very chill. People were very kind and explained the process from the onset. Interviews were a mixture of inperson and on zoom, so it was easy to plan accordingly.
Interview Questions: Why are you leaving your current job for this.

title: PhD Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Los Angeles, CA) in Jan 2021
Interview Descriptions: Excellent very comfortable environment. The environment was virtual so I was a bit worried but the interviewer was very nice and warm. I do not have any complaints. I was very fortunate to even have an interview, ya know lol.
Interview Questions: How us student life and research at Harvard?

title: Paleontologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University in Nov 2020
Interview Descriptions: Four video interviews, each with a different person and each lasted about an hour. Selection was made at the end of these interviews. Interview style varied widely from each person, from a casual conversation to typical interview and behavioral interview questions. This is the only institution that has called me for a rejection, rather than a rejection email. I'm assuming it was to show curtesy, but I would much prefer and email.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had a conflict in the work place

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I made a connection with a professor at Harvard who had received money from a grant.  I asked for a job, when none were advertised on the Harvard website.  Although the professor had help with others,  I got brought on nonetheless
Interview Questions: Nothing really.  Why do you want this job?

title: Staff 2 Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Has three rounds. One HR phone screening. The am in person. It ended up being a group interview with four other people. Was very unexpected.  Felt  very out of place. It was really awkward. Didn’t get it.
Interview Questions: How would you deal with a deadline?

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I had a 30 minute short phone call interview with a person from HR. They basically asked some questions regarding my experience for certain skillsets they wanted. The HR person was kind and patient. She replied to every one of my emails promptly and was quite encouraging. I ultimately didn't get the position because of my lack of experience, but the overall process was good.
Interview Questions: Can you go through your resume? Can you describe in more detail about what you did for social media marketing? What is effective communication? What experience do you have in communicating with institutions and universities? Expected salary, are you willing to relocate?

title: Scientist Interview
Application Type: The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA)
Interview Descriptions: To my dismay Harvard’s standards for vetting people have allowed them to miss the chance of hiring people that can be productive members of the team. The interviews went well and felt misled and discriminated against when I finally got to the reference checks. They required three, I provided five and my references confirmed with me afterwards. Harvard revoked my application because I couldn’t provide a reference from a place I got laid off from. Feeling awkward I went ahead reach out to my old colleagues at that company and got least three of the references. Harvard still denied it. No other company ask this and when you provide what they want, they can change their mind. It’s not professional at all.
Interview Questions: Can you provide at least three references, two of which are supervisors?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was overall pretty easy to navigate . It started with a phone interview , then a test which determined your ability to analyze some statistics. Interviewers were very nice and casual.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your experience

title: User Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions: Started with a phone screen through HR. Then I interviewed with my  Manager, my Manager's manager Team Members, and the CIO. Overall they were very responsive and transparent about the interview process.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you dealt with an upset customer.

title: Communications Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Aug 2020
Interview Descriptions: Interview process was very straightforward, starting with an initial phone screening. The phone screening involved confirming basic details about the position (schedule, salary range, etc.). The interviewer asked a few questions about my interest in the position and gave steps for what the remainder of the process would look like if I moved ahead.
Interview Questions: The interviewer confirmed basic details of the position (schedule, etc.) and asked about my interest in the position.

title: Communications and Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University in Jul 2020
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed with the HR for about 45 minutes then a week a later, had a follow up interview with the Director of the department. 3 days later, I had a final interview with 2 other members from different teams. The interview on the whole was pleasant.  I was disappointed that I had to follow up 2 weeks later before I was informed that a more suitable candidate had been selected. The worse part, I got a LinkedIn notification barely 3 days later that the job had been reposted
Interview Questions:
Run me through your CV and your job details as pertains to the role.
What courses did you take in school?

title: Assistant Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in May 2020
Interview Descriptions: Filled application online and got a response back within a few weeks to set up a phone screen. This was followed by a day of three interviews with various members of the team.
Interview Questions: I was asked how my fundraising experience in a different sector could be applied to academic fundraising.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Great interview process. Based on limited experience interview was designed to accommodate my expertise at the time. It was a very interactive process with great feedback. My interviewer was attentive during the whole process
Interview Questions: Describe how your background prepares you for this role

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: First there was a phone screen with HR. Very easy! Next I was brought in to meet with everyone in the office. At the end I met with the head of the whole department.
Interview Questions: They just wanted to know why I was interested in the job. No "behavioral" or tricky questions at all.

title: Program Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: The first interview was scheduled about six weeks after the submission of my application, and it was with the director of operation. The second interview was with the hiring manager.
Interview Questions:
What does success look like to you?
What was the last article that you have read recently?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Still waiting for a decision but the staff has been very patient and nice to return emails during this process, so I will keep waiting for the next following weeks.
Interview Questions: what is ur research interest? some questions about your thesis/dissertation?

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 7 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Following a successful phone screen with the recruiter, I had two, one-on-one in-person interviews with two senior staff in the department. A week or so later, I had another interview with a senior staff member from another department (someone they hadn't thought to include in the process before). The next morning, I was told I was the successful candidate.
Interview Questions: I was expecting a formal, behavioral interview--but the in-person interviews were actually far more informal conversations about my experience.

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Need to show knowledge of specific subject; in this case it was a finance undergrad class. If not own specialization during PhD work, where one can show transcript, then need to read to catch up and show knowledge in in-person interview.  Need to be graduate student at Harvard.
Interview Questions:
For finance undergrad classes: What are options/derivatives? 
What are the risks associated with short-selling?

title: Maintenance Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: fil out a application and then interview  start it part time and then I got a full time started it doing cleaning after three years they was a opening for maintenance and I applied for it
Interview Questions: if they need overtime if I would be available

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Process was pretty routine, nothing out of the ordinary. I was contacted by a recruiter early in the process  and then went through the interview process, which was also fairly in line with other interviews that I had had
Interview Questions: Overall process was pretty routine, nothing really out of the ordinary

title: Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Harvard University (Harvard, MA) in Nov 2019
Interview Descriptions: I met with the hiring manager who was very nice. He seemed impressed with my experience, but almost seemed to be trying to find a reason to not like me for the position.
Interview Questions: He listed several Joe tasks and asked me how I would prioritize them in terms of which one’s I would do first, and why.

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University in Nov 2019
Interview Descriptions: Clear interview process. Transparent Hiring team. I understood the scope of the role and desired skillset. Team was friendly to understand my desired career path as well. I worked in this role for the short term. I interviewed with 3-5 team members.
Interview Questions: Suitability for the role offered in the team.

title: Peer Advising Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Online application followed by in person interview with advising programs office. Also involved creating a unique study break idea. Involved very challenging behavioral questions specific to PAFing, specifically about how to deal with certain situations with pafees in problematic scenarios.
Interview Questions: How could you encourage people who don't attend study breaks to attend them?

title: Admissions Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Oct 2019
Interview Descriptions: Talked with the Admissions Managers in a group setting, completed two interviews, first interview was longer and lasted an hour and a half consisting of about 10 questions, second interview lasted 45 minutes.
Interview Questions: What does diversity, inclusion, and belonging mean to you?

title: Marketing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Great! They were clear about the role and appreciated my perspective. It was with three staff members on the marketing team and everyone was really nice. They were also effective at answering my questions related to diversity and work environment.
Interview Questions: How well do you work with data?

title: Project Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions: It turned out to be quite a long interview process. I had several phone interviews - one with the HR Manager, followed by one with the Project Director. One week later I took part in a 2 hour interview which was broken up into 4 interviews lasting 30 mins each. One week later I came in for a final interview with the Department Director and the HR Director which lasted in total 1 hour.
Interview Questions: I was asked about my reasons for wanting to work at Harvard and how I would fit with the culture and values held at the University. The remaining questions were behavioral type question focused on Communications, Teamwork/Collaboration, Problem Solving, Innovation, Dealing with Stressful Situations and where you see yourself in 5 years.

title: Assistant Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very difficult, and many academic and social questions were asked。I also asked many philosophical questions and values，And did some tests。I also provided some academic certificates and transcripts, as well as identity certificates and proof of no crime.
Interview Questions: How to look at the universe.

title: Economics 10 Unit Review Tutor Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Sept 2019
Interview Descriptions: Walkthrough a mock unit review test. Know how to lead students to answers without giving away the answer (but also while avoiding being overly obtuse). Anticipate potential follow-up questions since the interviewer will pretend to be a student, especially a student that gets answers slightly wrong
Interview Questions: Q: I don't understand why the price of related goods shifts demand. Can you explain?

title: Partner Engagement Coordinator At HGSE Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions:
Phone screening with HR for half-hour. Then invited onsite for in-person interview which consists of a 30 min interview with HR Director and then 1 hour with the rest of the team. I interviewed with a panel of 10 people on that day. There were so many people firing questions at you, honestly felt more like an interrogation than an interview. I prepared some questions at the end but barely had time to ask any before they ended the interview abruptly. 
After the interview, I sent thank you emails and then followed up but they said they needed a month to make the final decision. More than a month has gone by and I've never heard from them. I was very prepared and enthusiastic about the role, and have spent a lot of time researching their programs, but because of this experience, I don't I would apply to a specific department again.
Interview Questions: How would your coworkers or supervisors describe you?

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at Harvard University (Harvard, MA) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions: I was converted into the role from intern. It was farely simple for me to do the paperwork and the HR meetings.                                    I spent 3 days in training and then a online mini policy training.
Interview Questions: There where no interview questions

title: Student Library Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I was referred by a colleague who was working in the library. The process was pretty straight forward. I emailed my resume to my future advisor and received an email saying come for an interview and I did. The interviewer was very friendly. She asked me a few questions then explained everything in details.
Interview Questions: Asked about bilingual skill. Also asked some questions about my current research focus, my former experiences, and basic computer skills.

title: Admissions Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Jun 2019
Interview Descriptions: I was asked for a phone interview (15-20 minutes) after about 2 weeks since sending in an application. The interviewer called on time. She told me straight out that she had 15 questions and we had 20 minutes to answer them. She followed up saying that I didn't have to worry about time though.
Interview Questions: They told me they had to ask me what my minimum salary was.

title: Social Media Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I submitted my resume online, and I was contacted for an in person interview . I interviewed with two people one of their offices. It was a pretty informal process.
Interview Questions: What social media campaign ideas do you have?

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: After applying online, the interview process  for this new position included a phone screen interview with two people, followed by an on-campus interview, and then two weeks of waiting, and folllow up before hearing the final decision .
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time in which you have a difficult situation at work, and explain what you did to resolve the issue, and when the end result was.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: just email the faculty and  meet the faculty in person. why there is 30 words requirement? it is simply a simple interview. I don't know what else to say
Interview Questions: Why position? future plan?

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I got referred by a current employee and interviewed by the professor of the course that I applied weeks before the semester. The professor needs the TA to be highly engaged to this class and are able to arrange flexible schedules to fit in the need of the class.
Interview Questions: Please talk about an case study that is related to the course

title: Senior QA Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: The interview is entirely scenario based which is different than I had been used to.  They only ask questions that start with words like "tell me about a time when...."
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you had to work with a difficult person and how did you overcome that?

title: IT and Administrative Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I got a surprisingly poorly written email from the Chief Administrative Office for the Program for Evolutionary Dynamics, who invited me for an on-site interview. It was vague and didn’t inform me who exactly but I would be meeting with. I come in the following business week, and am met by the Director of the Program, who was friendly and professional. After a thorough and productive interview with him, he brought me to the Chief Administrative Officer’s Office, who came out in a rush and told me she forgot I was coming. What made this experience so unique was that she proceeded to bring me into a room, shut the door, and complained comprehensively about how incompetent her boss is and how miserable the job is I was applying to. The way in which she did this was whispering to me, out of some paranoia that the Director could hear her while he walked by the room, which just happened to have glass walls. The whole interview felt more like a therapy session for her rather than interviewing me.
Interview Questions: Why are you applying to a miserable role that will probably last forever since the term date on Harvard’s Employment website is inaccurate?

title: Staff Assistant III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: The process began with a screening call  that was very streamlined, general questions. This was followed by a phone interview with the Human Resources person in the specific department I was interviewing with. Then I was brought in to meet the team. The in person meeting consisted of one on ones and a group portion. This all took place within two to three weeks.
Interview Questions: What's the biggest challenge you've faced and how did you overcome it?

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Jan 2019
Interview Descriptions: Got an email for a phone interview, and afterwards to come in for an in-person interview. I’m not sure if the interviewer was having a bad day and I got the bad end of it, but I felt like I was wasting her precious time. When she walked in the first thing she asked was “do you have any questions for me?”. I was not sure how to answer since that’s not normally how an interview goes. She then seemed to roll her eyes every time I answered a question and kept staring at her watch. Oh and she also told me that it was Harvard so people expect full professionalism in what employees wear. Making it seem like my business-casual outfit wasn’t up to par, even though she was in a tank top. I have never left an interview feeling so defeated and belittled.
Interview Questions: Basic questions, explain a time you went above and beyond.

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Jan 2019
Interview Descriptions: Got invited for a weekend with other prospective students. After a few presentations and breakfast, we had the chance to meet with current professors. After that, we were treated with dinner drinks with current students, as well as a brunch with professors and students.
Interview Questions: Why are choosing to pursue a PhD in Biostatistics? Tell me about your past research experiences. What biostatistics research are you interested in?

title: Adjunct Lecturer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at Harvard University (New York, NY) in Jan 2019
Interview Descriptions: Rude, smug, no respect. selfish big headed individuals with no cope on or regard for anyone else but themselves. Money was bad and not worth the amount of hours i put in.
Interview Questions: What is your education? Where do you see yourself in 5 years?

title: Student Affairs Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Initial resume screening (HR professionals), phone screening with full-time HR staff in addition to hiring consultant, 2:1 interview with department staff.  All very timely, details communicated clearly through  email.  Very courteous call from HR and good feedback (after not getting the position).
Interview Questions: What led you to be interested in this position?

title: HR Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Dec 2018
Interview Descriptions: The interview process involved a phone interview from a consultant, an in person interview, and final round interview.  The final decision was made after a panel reviewed the application.  The full timeline took close to three months to complete.
Interview Questions: Behavioral interviewing questions:  Tell us about a situation where you had a disagreement with someone on your team and how did you handle the situation?

title: PR Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Dec 2018
Interview Descriptions: Heard back via email about a month after applying for the position online. Phone interview was arranged for the following week and lasted about 50 mins. Interviewer was kind and professional, happy to answer questions and provide more info about the position. Unsure whether the next step is another phone interview or a sit-down.
Interview Questions: Asked to provide specific examples of PR strategies you've pitched in the past.

title: IT Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Had a phone screen with the recruiter, had to answer some clarifying questions about my technical abilities, then it would have been an in-person with the hiring manager. It was not very conversational, felt very robotic. For the most part I was asked to summarize each of my past jobs and things that could have been answered by actually looking at my resume/application. I didn’t get an opportunity to ask any questions which is strange as this is a very usual interview practice. I withdrew after the first phone screen as I was told upfront they would not be able to meet my salary range, which is market rate for my field. They said budgets are set and due to being a non-profit higher ed institution, there was no flexibility on salary. I really do understand that’s how things can go in any organization or company, but…they made it sound like they were some small school with a limited budget. Everyone knows the wealth that Harvard has. Trying to pull the “we’re in education and budgets are limited” at the school with the largest endowment in the world comes off as incredibly tone deaf and out of touch.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work here?

title: Publications Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: It was quite a lengthy process: I had four interviews (including a phone interview with HR), and met with different parts of the team each time. I was also given a copyediting assignment, and was asked to submit a design portfolio. I met with the woman who is now my boss, her supervisor, and two members of the communication team who are now my colleagues.
Interview Questions: What is one of your weaknesses?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Nov 2018
Interview Descriptions: I was interviewed at a Lab at Harvard to be a Research Assistant. I message them the previous semester and got a response saying they already had all the staff needed but a semester later they contacted me to offer an interview for that new semester.  It was for a non-paid position as an Undergraduate Research Assistant. They were really open and clearly explained to me the different lines of research they were doing, I think that what mattered most for them was how many hours people would commit to the role.
Interview Questions: Do you have any question for us?

title: Research Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Nov 2018
Interview Descriptions: The interviewer did not have interesting questions. He/she was only interested in negotiating salary down, rather than understanding my motivations and qualifications for taking the job.  I did not have to do any lengthy preparation for the interview. and they did not include any interviews with the team.
Interview Questions: My skills

title: Faculty Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Nov 2018
Interview Descriptions: The interview process involves a phone screen, followed by a series of interviews. You will interview with the manager, a panel of your peers, and the faculty you will ultimately support. The questions remain consistent for many of these interviews so the process is pretty straightforward.
Interview Questions: This job often includes competing priorities. How do you manage your time and prioritize to accomplish all the required tasks?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Skype interview. Go me through your resume. Submit my resume. Get a phone call. typical question about my previous research. They give me the info about the project. Applying for visa take time. No real support to move to Boston
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work in this lab?

title: Program Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA)
Interview Descriptions: Initially, Harvard HR interviews over the phone, then it goes to a phone call with the Director of FXB. A third interview of the phone with the PI. A final interview was done in Boston in person.
Interview Questions: I don't recall the interview questions but they were very general, especially in the first round. Tell us about your skills, etc. During the in-person interview, they are keen to know about your field experience.

title: IT/AV Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Oct 2018
Interview Descriptions: Initially submitted resume and asked for an on-site interview at Harvard. There were three interviewers. The interview consisted typical behavioral questions. The interviewers were no fun to talk to. Not a single smile on their faces throughout the whole interview process. One of them even left during the interview which was extremely disrespectful. Overall a very bad interview experience. Sent a thank you note out of my will and never heard back
Interview Questions: Typical behavioral questions involving group works, failure and past experiences

title: Student Financial Services Account Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: The interview process began with a phone screening, 2 in person interviews, two writing test and a reference check. I had my first in person interview scheduled 3 weeks after the phone screening was conducted. The first interview was with a panel of 3 people.  I went in for the second interview about 3 weeks after the first one and interviewed with the HR Manager, I also had a group interview with 9 other people, as well as a writing test that consisted of 2 writing samples. After a couple weeks I was asked for my references and after about a week from then I as contacted and informed HR decided not to move forward with my candidacy.
Interview Questions: What computer software are you fluent in?

title: Archivist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Sept 2018
Interview Descriptions: They were nice and polite. It was a positive experience. It was a phone interview. They described the roll in detail. They answered questions about their work experience. Regular interview questions.
Interview Questions: They asked about work experience.

title: Undergraduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Sept 2018
Interview Descriptions: The interview was done on campus. It was made to feel like a conversation and was enjoyable due to being able to feel relatively relaxed in the interview. Talked about my extracurricular activities and interests
Interview Questions: Extracurricular activities and interests- the conversation progressed naturally from there

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Aug 2018
Interview Descriptions: I had a series of interviews, which were welcoming and a positive experience. The hiring process was fast, because they needed to fill the position. Interviews with more senior people were very informal. The more stringent questions came from more junior staff.
Interview Questions: How would you build credibility with students? What kinds of partnerships can you bring to the job?

title: Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Jul 2018
Interview Descriptions: I applied online directly with Harvard through their website and received an email asking me to pick an interview time. It was flexible as there were plenty of times available. The recruiter called promptly and everything went well except the end during salary discussions. The posted salary grade was #54 which meant $50,055-$78,918 according to their own website. I already make mid $60s in a city with a much lower cost of living than Boston and they were only willing to pay mid $50s and it didn't seem like they were willing to negotiate at all. Meanwhile, a similar job position in Boston at a private firm was offering $70-$75k. I'm surprised that such a prestiguous institution would be so cheap. Their compensation analysts might want to do some more studying on the market and restructure their salary grades.
Interview Questions: What relevant skills do you have for this position? Do you have experience with excel? Are you comfortable working in a smaller group within a larger unit?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: There was only one round. Very easy, straightforward question. Nothing technical or trying to give you hard time. Lasted around 40 mins. I met all my colleages and boss.
Interview Questions: Your past project.

title: Program Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Jun 2018
Interview Descriptions: Called me through an agency, invited me for the interview, they were looking for an aid an gave me the position 2 days after the interview and I started the job before the end of the month
Interview Questions: My Expreinceces? Challenges? Feedback

title: Director, Operations I-Lab Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Phone screen with a third party company.  The call only lasted about 30 minutes and was very focused on asking me several questions.  They were looking for someone who had experience with startups and the venture capital community.
Interview Questions: What facilities experience did I have?   Who do you know in the Venture Capital industry.

title: Volunteer Applications Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions:
I submitted my application late February 

1)  Did a HR phone  screening in early March
2)  First round of interviews with 3 people for a half hour each: 1 Skype interview with HR; 2 with members of the team.
3) Did a 2 page case study
4) Second round of interviews with 2 people for half hour each:  1 with HR; 1 with a different member of the team
5) Had to submit 5 professional references.  In my case I submitted 6.
6) Received a conditional offer letter on the final day in April while final background checks were being done.
7)Received a final offer letter a week later once final background checks were completed.
Interview Questions: What skills and experiences would you bring to this position?

title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions:
First there was a phone interview that lasted approximately 1 hour. Within a few weeks, they flew me out for an on-site interview. I had to pay out of pocket to book my hotel and flight, but was later reimbursed. The onsite consisted of meeting with the PI I'd work for, a lab/facilities tour, a one hour presentation by me to the group, then several one-on-one meetings with the director of the center and various other people. Lunch was in a conference room where other postdocs gave me presentations of their research and I asked them questions. There wasn't really any one-on-one time with other postdocs, as the PI was in the lunch room with us. I wish I would have had some one-on-one time with the other postdocs so I could have asked questions about the PI's management style.

During the portion of the interview with the director, I was offered the position on the spot. I verbally accepted. The official letter came later. 

Surprisingly, the hardest part of the process has been the onboarding. It's a dual appointment with BWH, and BWH has been extremely rude and unhelpful throughout the process. I feel as if I didn't press issues on my end (like setting up the occupational health screening, etc) then my start date would have been continually pushed back (it was already delayed by 1 week). The go-to person at BWH has been a nightmare to work with and has said things like "you are taking up too much of my time," "I will apologize on your behalf to HR for contacting them," "now you have wasted my time," etc., when I have e-mailed questions and waited for more than 5 days for a response. The whole onboarding process literally almost made me want to throw my hands up and look for a position elsewhere. It was the most unwelcoming thing I have ever experienced as a new hire!! I can only hope my interaction with this person ends after this stage and it's smooth sailing from here out. 

The interview process was actually amazing. If you come prepared and knowledgeable about the lab you're joining, then there shouldn't be anything to worry about. I was not at all expecting to be offered the position on the spot. The only thing that affected my overall experience was dealing with this super negative person for my actual onboarding. (There were absolutely no problems with the center I'm joining or Harvard in general, just with BWH).
Interview Questions:
What is my philosophy on life? 
Technical questions regarding my presentation. My presentation was interrupted as I was giving it and the audience asked me questions as I went along. This meant the 1 hour presentation really was about 1 hour 20 minutes, plus extra questions from the group at the end.
How do I deal with conflict?
Do I get along with people?
What kind of project am I interested in?
Am I good with computers?
How would I interpret certain data?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in May 2018
Interview Descriptions: Talked to me about my previous experiences, as well as posed potential tasks, and asked how I would tackle them. I spoke to my research background and how I could integrate that experience to the technical projects of the job.
Interview Questions: How do you work in a team setting?

title: Summer Camp Counselor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Had a phone interview with the site director and then an in-person hands-on trial... basically helping to staff one of the off-season events for an hour, so the director could see how I interacted with the kids. I got a verbal offer and then it was followed up with written contract etc.
Interview Questions: My previous experience with kids

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions: On phone interview  followed by in person interview and tour of facilities. Process was easy. On phone interview lasted 15 minutes, in person interview lasted less than 1 hour. Was not offered position
Interview Questions: What are your strengths

title: IT Consultant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (New York, NY) in Mar 2018
Interview Descriptions: Very simple and straightforward.  Infrastructure, research opportunities, fundamental & applied research are all perks to the job. As a consultant, you have to work in partnership with clients, advising them how to use information technology in order to meet their business objectives or overcome problems. You'll work to improve the structure and efficiency of IT systems in various organisations.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with angry people asking you to troubleshoot their laptop issues?

title: Staff Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 9 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions:
I’ve been trying to get a job at Harvard for almost three years and every time I think it’s finally going to happen they end up going with someone else. Last year I figured I’d try to get my foot in the door by temping, so I accepted a three month long assignment that paid $14/hr, hoping it would be an investment...

After three months, the person I was covering for came back.  But I was thrilled  when the department called me back a month later,  asking me to fill in again. It turned out the original person left for good, so there was now an open position available! 

I truly thought this was my lucky break, since they requested me back for the same role that was now open. But whenever I asked about the timeframe to actually be hired, they would just say they’re not sure what the new role will look like and that I should basically treat every day like an audition for the job. This went on for three months (so by now I was there for a total of six months and getting more and more stressed).

 After they maxed out the time they could keep me as a temp, they decided to make me a Term employee for three months, hyping it up to seem like a huge success. But whenever I asked my supervisor for projects that would allow me to leave a foot print and prove myself, she would just tell me she appreciates my proactiveness, but unfortunately “it’s not appropriate because you’re a Term employee”.  So, I made sure to keep a spreadsheet of everything I did, and tried to build solid relationships with my co-workers. My supervisor and the Director even told me on numerous occasions that all of the reviews they’d gotten about me were  been very positive. 

However, towards the end of my term end date,  one of the managers gave me a very generic interview and barely glanced at the spreadsheet. And when I asked the department director a few days later if there are any updates, he told me I wasn’t even chosen as a finalist for the position. 

I wish I knew what was going through their minds as they put me through this experience, and why they wanted to keep me around as long as they did if they weren’t intending to hire me permanently.
Interview Questions: How do you measure success?

title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions: I was introduced to the principal investigator and we discussed about the projects available. Our interests overlap. I started in the lab with my own fellowship funding and now been hired for the next 2 years.
Interview Questions: What were the skills I would like to develop during my postdoc

title: Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions: Very long process had to be there for three hours, interviewed 3 different people. Unnecessary waiting time. Repetitive process, not very pleasant, not even water offered. I was placed in a conference room, having interviews of 30 - 45 min each. Within 15 min wait between interviewees. Very old fashion process.
Interview Questions: Years of experience, what can I bring to the position, salary expectations.

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (New York, NY) in Feb 2018
Interview Descriptions: just had the Skype interview,  I had talked with two professors in the Department of Radiology. The whole process was just in one hour. They ask some projects I have done in details and shared some details of the project.
Interview Questions: what is your plan in next three years?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: I met with several professors in the department over the course of a day. We discussed their research and what I wanted to study during my PhD. It was very informal.
Interview Questions: What was the most interesting thing you studied as an undergraduate?

title: PhD Candidate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Jan 2018
Interview Descriptions: Talk to three or four different professors, they question you about your previous research and you hear about their own research. Usually the length of the interview is around 30 minutes.
Interview Questions: Describe your previous research experience.

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA)
Interview Descriptions: The interview was fairly informal. All participants were together around a small table. Myself included. I was made to feel welcome and comfortable. The interview felt more like a conversation about how we can be musically beneficial than an interrogation.
Interview Questions: How have you addressed situations you may encounter in the course of this job in the past?

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Dec 2017
Interview Descriptions: 1-hour interview one on none with PI then lunch with lab.  The process was really to get to know me.  They wanted someone that will work well within the culture of the lab.
Interview Questions: What drives you to do research?

title: Marketing Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Dec 2017
Interview Descriptions:
I was reached out to by a recruiter from their Human Resources Department to discuss with me about my qualifications and if I would be a good fit for their department. A few days alter I was reached out to again about an in person interview. The in person interview lasted about an hour in a half and I met with about 7 different people in small groups. They asked all sorts of questions including what CMS the company I worked for previously used. Make sure you know everything and anything before this in person interview. In advanced they tell you who you are meeting with so do your research. Make sure you know as much as you can about each person and what their role is incase they ask you questions about what you think their role does. 

After the interview was over they said that they would get back to me within a week if they wanted to move forward. I emailed each person thanking them for taking the time to meet with me. I waited a week before reaching out to the hiring manager about the position and they said they hadnt made any decisions. I waited another 3 weeks and then again they said they are still deciding. Finally 2 more weeks later I tried to get another update and they said they didnt want to move forward with me.
Interview Questions: What CMS did the company you previously worked for use?

title: Media Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA)
Interview Descriptions: I was contacted by a recruiter, who set up a phone interview. I had a phone interview with the recruiter, and then was brought in for an in person interview two weeks later. Spent an hour and a half at the in person interview. Waited 3 weeks, and then they set up the second in person interview. That interview was a half hour. I didn't hear back for three weeks, and then got a form e-mail, saying I wasn't hired. I would have appreciated hearing back from the actual people who interviewed me. Considering how long the process was (2.5 months), you'd think they would have the courtesy to personally inform me that I didn't receive the position.
Interview Questions: What are your weaknesses?

title: A/V Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: The interviewer was nice and there was only 1 round of interview. It was more about attitude and behavioral questions. I heard back from them very soon, which took about 2 weeks. (It was a co-op position)
Interview Questions: Why did you want to work here? Describe your work style.

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University in Nov 2017
Interview Descriptions: It was a phone interview  for almost an hour. I was asked mostly about projects and I had to explain more than one project. I didn't hear back from them almost for a month after my phone interview. Then when I followed up for the update, my email was replied within 24 hours.
Interview Questions: How large was the volume of data in my previous projects?

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions:
I applied online through Harvard's Career site--I applied one day after the job was first posted. 23 days after I submitted my application, I was contacted by a staff member for a phone screen. That phone screen occurred three days later. The interview itself was very conversational--it seemed the staff member genuinely cared about my experience. Following the interview,  she said I would hear back within 1-2 weeks. I sent a follow-up  thank you email the next day.  I did not hear back within 1-2 weeks so at the 3-week mark, I emailed her again. Within a few hours, she emailed back and said they were not moving forward with my candidacy. Though I obviously did not move forward, overall, the process was pleasant. 

Below are the actual interview questions. In total, I was asked 14 questions (I've listed the standard, behavioral questions). The other questions (that I did not list) were very nuanced toward my own experience and education.
Interview Questions: What caused you to react to this position?

title: Research Project and Data Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: It took roughly three month because of internal hold-ups.  Interviewed with a recruiter over the phone, then the PI and manager and then met in person.  Was asked for references two days later and was given an offer a week later.
Interview Questions: What is your five year plan?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions:
Process moved quickly.  I applied online and was called for a phone screening just a week later, which lasted about 30 minutes and asked basic questions like my previous experience, ability to do the job, why I want to be involved with the project, etc.  Lots of description of the position, which I appreciated.  The email said that the call would last about 15 minutes but it was more like 30, which I saw as a good thing.  They wanted to know a lot of details about my current position and work.  The phone screening was ended with the scheduling of a Skype meeting with other people in the department.  This is where the process got frustrating.

I was on Skype waiting for the interviewer to connect and they were running late.  They then sent me an email saying that they had "written down the wrong time" for the interview and asked if I could do it an hour later, which I did.  After waiting over an hour to speak, this interview was exactly the same as the phone screening.  Same questions, same answers, but to one other person, in addition to the person I spoke with on the phone.  Why wouldn't they share the information  from my phone screening and then ask me different, more in depth questions on Skype?  Aside from all that, it went as well as it could, and about 3 days later I was offered a more formal Skype interview with the professor that I would potentially be working alongside.  I was told that this would be the final interview for the position, so I felt good about that.

For the final interview, there were even more problems.  They were on time this time, but they had very serious technical difficulties connecting to Skype and using their camera and microphone.  I was patient and even helped them out with getting it connected properly.  This all took about 30 minutes.  Once we finally got connected, the professor said that he had to go to another meeting that was very important and was sorry that we couldn't talk.  The assistant who had done the first few interviews with me asked me just a few questions, but sort of rushed me because I guess the room was booked up for another group to use and she had to get out.  Basically, I sat there for 30 minutes while they tried to get connected and then did not get to have a real interview with real questions.  I wasn't even given time to give real answers.  

I emailed saying that I understood the technical difficulties but would like to have another chance, if possible.  No answer.  I emailed two weeks later asking the same thing, and this time was an immediate answer:  We picked someone else.

I have interviewed for these positions at several top universities and I am stricken at how unprofessional almost every person at Harvard was throughout this whole process.  It made it very frustrating.  I feel that I should have been told that there was a time restriction on my final interview and I feel that I should have been given another chance.  None of it was my fault.  I got pushed out of an interview that I was very excited and very prepared for.  I feel that I gave a lot of good information and good answers in the initial phone screening, but wasn't even given a chance to do that in the later interviews, when it mattered a lot more.

Despite all this, I feel that I did as well as I could have and the interview questions were relatively easy.  The entire process took about 3-4 weeks, which is very fast.  I think that this was a one-time (very) bad experience and I will continue to apply for positions here, obviously.  The lesson I took from this is that from now on, I am going to avoid Skype meetings if it is possible.  If I had made the trip for an in-person interview, I might have this job right now.  But on the other hand, it was they who offered the Skype interview, so they should've had the equipment set up, tested, ready to go.  Don't offer it if you can't do it.
Interview Questions:
What is your experience?
Describe experience and skills. (LOTS of this...they wanted to know specific, minute details of my current responsibilities)
Why do you want to work on this project?
What are your future plans?
How do you see yourself contributing to the project in a meaningful way?

title: CDL Driver Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Harvard University (Allston, MA)
Interview Descriptions: It's a very planned interview. Your references are checked. There a drug test as well. You meet all the staff in the department. You are trained with one of the drivers/dispatchers. You drive the vehicles in training. And fuel the vehicles as well .You check the equipment, and send the notice to the maintenance department. Always check the schedule twice during your shift. Be prepared  to work different shifts. Check in on the two-way radio . Acknowled to dispatch when leaving and returning from base. Wear the uniform issued by the school. At times report for duty at least 45 minutes before your shift.
Interview Questions: That would be commitment 100%.

title: Student Worker Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Harvard University (Cambridge, MA) in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions: Very relaxed and nice, my (now) supervisor just wanted to get to know me and my way of working, she asked me about my former work and study experiences, told me about the future job responsibilities and tasks; we talked about additional functions at the workplace that I could take on
Interview Questions: What did you do in your function of X, as stated on your resume?

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Harvard University (Boston, MA) in Sept 2017
Interview Descriptions: Mails and meetings, about what I have done before and some new work the professor is going to do. See if my skills match these requests and whether I am interested in his field of work
Interview Questions: Did you have any research experience?

title: Staff Assistant III Interview

Interview Descriptions: The hiring and interview process, for me, lasted 3 months. That included first round, second round, third round, and final round. Also included skills based testing and reference checks. Beginning with a phone interview, the process culminated with an in person panel interview.
Interview Questions: How do you alter your presentation when speaking with a peer versus with a donor and/or high level manager?

title: User Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Harvard University in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone screening, then two in-person interviews with several people. The whole process took over a month I believe, but it was well worth it. They split up the interviews so I wasn't speaking to more than two people at a time, which I appreciated. I find panel interviews to be way more stressful than necessary. My first set of interviews felt a bit rushed, probably because the people interviewing me were conscious of going over into someone else's time. However, the second set was more relaxed and went over the time allotted because they wanted to provide as much information about the position as possible.
Interview Questions: How have you dealt with users that are frustrated/stressed out?

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: Pre-interview written assignment (sample tasks related to the job), two phone interviews and then a reference check. Standard interview questions and process, but very little small talk, ice breaker conversation at the beginning, which made it a little more stressful than necessary.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had to manage up

title: Special Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Harvard University
Interview Descriptions: First, I interviewed with the director of Human Resources for about forty five minutes and then for the next forty five minutes I interviewed with the member of the dean's office that would be directly supervising me in the position.
Interview Questions: How would you manage multiple stakeholders?
